englishTranslation: We were going to be here.
vocabIncluded: using Ir and "a" to put verbs in the future (e.g. "voy a ser")
íbamos: "were going", "we were going" (Ir, imperfect, 1st person plural)

englishTranslation: You left with them(f)?
vocabIncluded: ella: "them" after a preposition (fem. prep. pronoun)
irse: any use of Ir with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to "leave"

englishTranslation: You all want to do it like we do it?
vocabIncluded: ustedes: "you" plural, subject pronoun (3rd-person plural treatment)

englishTranslation: She thinks they went to Bogotá.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)

englishTranslation: They are going(currently) to the place.
vocabIncluded: al: "to the" before a masculine noun

englishTranslation: I heard she was going to be a lawyer.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
iba: "was going", "he/she/it was going" (Ir, imperfect, 3rd person)
using Ir and "a" to put verbs in the future (e.g. "voy a ser")

spanishExample: *I hope* que ella vaya cuando nosotros vayamos.
englishTranslation: I hope she goes when we go.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)

spanishExample: *I hope* que te vayas de ese lugar.
englishTranslation: I hope you leave from that place.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)

englishTranslation: I want them to go to the place.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
al: "to the" before a masculine noun

spanishExample: Yo no me iba a ir.
englishTranslation: I wasn’t going to leave.
vocabIncluded: iba: "was going", "I was going" (Ir, imperfect, 1st person)
irse: any use of Ir with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to "leave"
using Ir and "a" to put verbs in the future (e.g. "voy a ser")

englishTranslation: They were going to be doctors.
vocabIncluded: iban: "were going", "they were going" (Ir, imperfect, 3rd person plural)
using Ir and "a" to put verbs in the future (e.g. "voy a ser")

englishTranslation: You were going to go with them(m).
vocabIncluded: ibas: "were going", "you were going" (Ir, imperfect, 2nd person)
using Ir and "a" to put verbs in the future (e.g. "voy a ser")

spanishExample: Me *they told* que no me fui.
englishTranslation: They told me I didn’t leave.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
me: "me" as an indirect object ("to me", "for me")

spanishExample: Me voy de la casa ahora.
englishTranslation: I’m leaving the house now.
vocabIncluded: irse: any use of Ir with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to "leave"

spanishExample: Me *you told* que te vas ahora.
englishTranslation: You told me you are leaving now.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
me: "me" as an indirect object ("to me", "for me")

englishTranslation: They haven’t left yet.
vocabIncluded: han: "have", "they have" before a participle (Haber, present, 3rd person plural)

spanishExample: No se irá *unless* le *you tell* eso.
englishTranslation: He won’t leave unless you tell him that.
vocabIncluded: irá: "will go", "he/she/it will go" (Ir, future, 3rd person)
le: "her/him" as an indirect object ("to her/him", "for her/him")

englishTranslation: They don’t want me to leave.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)

spanishExample: Nos fuimos de la casa muy *early.*
englishTranslation: We left from the house very early.
She’s leaving before sunset.
vocabIncluded: irse: any use of Ir with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to "leave"

spanishExample: Si lo vas a hacer así, estará mal.
englishTranslation: If you’re going to do it like this, it’ll be wrong.
vocabIncluded: así: adverb meaning "this way", "that way", "like this", "like that"
estará: "will be", "he/she/it will be" (Estar, future, 3rd person)
using Ir and "a" to put verbs in the future (e.g. "voy a ser")

englishTranslation: We’re going to do our chores(m).
vocabIncluded: using Ir and "a" to put verbs in the future (e.g. "voy a ser")

englishTranslation: They go to the place with you all.
vocabIncluded: al: "to the" before a masculine noun
ustedes: plural "you" after a preposition (prep. pronoun)

englishTranslation: She already left.
vocabIncluded: ya: adverb meaning "anymore", "already", and a variety of other time-related things
